bibl.title: Letter from Edwin C. Shaw to Henry Rose Carter, August 1, 1919

div1.p: Shaw requests Carter's advice in establishing a city public health clinic in Akron, Ohio.

div1.head: Letter from Edwin C. Shaw to Henry Rose Carter, August 1, 1919
div1.p:
EDWIN C. SHAW
533 SECOND NATIONAL BUILDING
Akron, Ohio
August 1st,
1 9 1 9. Dr. H. C. Carter,
U. S. Deputy Public Health Officer,
Bureau of Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor:

Following the custom generally observed, I believe,
about the country, the Mayor of Akron has appointed a Committee
to suggest the best type of memorial for Akron's contribution
to the ending of the war. This Committee includes some who
have long felt that Akron needed a Polyclinic, a building de-
signed, equipped and manned to coordinate all the social acti-
vities of the town and county as well as the curative and corr-
ectional facilities to round out a better health control. It
has been our idea that if all the social activities of the
community as well as the health activities as met by the different
kinds of medical clinics such as eye, ear, nose, throat, dental,
baby welfare, and psychiatric, were in the same building under
competent central direction, the result would be of inestimable
value to the community.

I have discussed the different phases of the proposed
plans with Dr. Phillip King Brown, Dr. Richard Cabot and Dr.
Lewellys F. Barker. The splendid way in which these gentlemen
have responded to my inquiry prompts me to write you in the hope
that you also may find it convenient to give me the benefit of
your ideas and knowledge as a result of your studies in welfare
and health work. Perhaps you may be willing to make such
recommendations as would be of aid to avoid making the Polyclinic
a purely diagnostic one.

I have had some notion that it might be possible to
effect a very good service without involving a pecuniary sacrifice
on the part of physicians by paying them for a certain fixed time
at the Clinic in proportion to their yearly earnings, and so
arranging their contact with the patient that the demand on their
time might be reduced to the minimum; first, by so arranging the
appointments that the Polyclinic would have an even load each
day; and second, by employment of a proper kind of clerk and over-
seer to relieve the physician of so much of detail as would be
involved in taking histories, answering questions, etc., as are
preliminary to diagnosis, which when systematized, can be asked
by the non-professional as well as by the doctor himself.

EDWIN C. SHAW
533 SECOND NATIONAL BUILDING
Akron, Ohio
-2-
8-1-19. Dr. H. C. Carter---------

With this plan and with the thought that the Clinic would not
be limited to diagnostic work only, but that it would deliver
general outpatient aid, a very great service could be rendered
to the community.

May I trouble you for an expression of opinion as
to the desirability and the practicability of the plan suggested!

The desirability of having the benefit of your
judgment at the earliest convenient date, together with the un-
certainty of the mails, prompts me to send this inquiry by
registered mail.

Please accept in advance my grateful appreciation
for any assistance you may find it convenient to give us.

Yours very truly,
E C Shaw.
